content: 51We envisaged us-ing this approach as a crystal design strategy to form a series of functional organic1College of Chemistry and Material Science, andGuangdong Provincial Key Laboratory ofFunctional Supramolecular CoordinationMaterials and Applications, Jinan University,Guangzhou 510632, China2Department of Chemistry and MaterialsInnovation Factory, University of Liverpool, 51Oxford Street, Liverpool L7 3NY, UK3School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering,Institution for Energy Research, JiangsuUniversity, Zhenjiang 212013, China4Central Laser Facility, Research Complex atHarwell, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory,Harwell OX11 0QX, UK5Department of Chemistry, Imperial CollegeLondon, Molecular Sciences Research Hub,White City Campus, Wood Lane, London W120BZ, UK6Lead contact*Correspondence:guohongning@jnu.edu.cn (G.-H.N.),malittle@liverpool.ac.uk (M.A.L.),aicooper@liverpool.ac.uk (A.I.C.)https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chempr.2021.09.016ll3158 Chem 7, 3157每3170, November 11, 2021Articlecage co-crystals, by considering how a wide range of guests (e.g., with different vol-umes, sizes, and shapes) could be inserted into the ＆＆virtual pores＊＊ in a porous host.

S3 2. Supplemental experimental data  2-1.  Synthesis of 1,8-diaminoanthracene   Scheme S1. Synthesis of 1,8-diaminoanthracene.

1,8-diaminoanthracene was prepared as reported in the literature from 1,8 -dinitroquinone using a modifi ed procedure .1,2   Synthesis of 1,8 -diaminoanthraquinone:  1,8-dinitroanthraquinone  (6.2 g, 20 mmol) and Na2S?9H 2O (19.5 g, 75.5 mmol ) in a mixture of ethanol  (100 mL) and water ( 400 mL ) was heated under reflux for 8 h ours. The resultant red suspension was cooled to room temperature and then poured into ice -water. The red precipitate was collected  by filtrations , washed with excess water, and dried to give 4.8  g of the product as a red powder .

Yield: 97%. 1H NMR (CDCl 3, 400 MHz, 298 K): 汛 (ppm) 7.62 (dd , 1JHH = 1.1 Hz, 2JHH = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 7.41 (dd, 1JHH = 7.4 Hz, 2JHH = 8.3 Hz, 2H) and 6.94  (dd, 1JHH =1.1 Hz, 2JHH = 8.3 Hz, 2H) and 6.75 (br oad s , -NH 2, 4H).

Synthesis of 1,8 -diaminoanthracene: The reaction was carried out in the dark. A solution of 1,8 -diaminoanthraquinone (2.0 g, 8.4 mmol) in isopropanol (100 ml) was degassed  with nitrogen for 15 minutes.

Sodium borohydride (4.0 g, 106 mmol) was then added portion -wise into the reaction mixture. The resulting suspension was heated under reflux for 60 h under a nitrogen atmosphere . The reaction was then cool ed to room temperature before being poured on to ice /water (250 mL). The dark precipitates were removed by filtration , washed thoroughly with water  and hexane, and then purifi ed by column chromatography on a silica gel column  using 0-3% methanol in chloroform as the eluent. The product was obtained as a dark red solid in an overall yield of 50 %  (0.87 g). 1H NMR (CDCl 3, 400 MHz, 298 K): 汛 (ppm) 8.35 (d, JHH = 8.5 Hz,  2H), 7.49 (d, JHH = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.30 (d, JHH = 7.2 Hz,  1H), 7.28 (d, JHH 7.2 Hz,  1H), 6.76 (d, JHH = 7.0 Hz,  2H).

OONO2 NO2Na2SEtOH / H2OOONH2 NH2NaBH 4IPANH2 NH2 S4 2-2.  Synthesis of the Anthracene -based cage (1)   Scheme S2. Synthesis of 1  Sc(OTf) 3 (40 mg, 0.081 mmol) in CH 3CN (10 mL) was added dropwise t o a solution of benzene -1,3,5 -tricarbaldehyde (100.0 mg, 0.62 mmol), 1,8 -diaminoanthracene (192.7 mg, 0.93 mmol) and molecular sieves (3 ?) in chloroform (200 mL) at room temperature . The brown -green solution was stirred at room temperature for 16 hours, and reaction mixture was filtrated to remove insoluble polymer and molecular sieves. The resulting  brown filtrate was concentrated to 30 mL, and then 400 mL hexane was adde d to precipitate the cage molecule 1 (143 mg) as brown powder in an overall yield of 56 %.  1H NMR (CDCl 3, 500 MHz, 298 K): 汛 (ppm) 8.54 (s, H6, 6H), 8.52 (s, H7, 6H), 8.47 (s, H4, 3H), 8.32 (s, H5, 3H), 7.86 (d, 2JHH = 8.5 Hz, H3,  6H), 7.46 (dd, 1JHH = 7.0 Hz, 2JHH = 8.5 Hz, 6H) and 6.87 (d, 2JHH = 7.0 Hz, H1,  6H). 13C NMR (CDCl 3, 125 MHz, 300 K): 汛 (ppm) 161.1, 150.7, 137.0, 132.3, 131.0, 126.1, 125.7, 125.0, 118.7 and 111.2.  HR-MS (CI, CH 4): m/z calcd . for [(C 60H36N6)+H]+: 841.3080 (M)+; found, 841.3081.

2-3.  General pr oced ures for preparing host-guest cage co-crystals   As-synthesized cage 1 (20 mg, 24 米mol) was dissolved in 1,4 -dioxane (10 mL). The resulting suspension was  filtrated through a syringe filter (PTEF, pore size 0.2 米m, Whatman) to give a n orange solution .  The guest molecule (48 米mol)  in powdered form was dissolved into the orange filtrate  and the result ing mixture was divided into 10 bathes (1  mL x 10). Slow diffusion of n-pentane into the cage -guest mixture in 1,4 -dioxane afforded co -crystals of the host -guest complexes that were suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis.

Materials and methodsAnthracene-based cage (1) synthesisSc(OTf) 3(40 mg, 0.081 mmol) in CH 3CN (10 mL) was added dropwise to a solution ofbenzene-1,3,5-tricarbaldehyde (100.0 mg, 0.62 mmol), 1,8-diaminoanthracene(192.7 mg, 0.93 mmol) and molecular sieves (3 A ?) in chloroform (200 mL). The brown-green solution was stirred at room temperature for 16 h, and the reaction mixture wasthen ?ltered to remove the insoluble polymer by-products and molecular sieves. The re-sulting brown ?ltrate was concentrated to 30 mL under reduced pressure at room tem-perature, and then 400 mL hexane was added to precipitate the cage molecule 1, whichwas isolated as brown powder in an overall yield of 56%: 143 mg.

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chempr.2021.09.016llArticleOrganic cage inclusion crystals exhibitingguest-enhanced multiphoton harvestingGuo-Hong Ning,1,2,*Peng Cui,2,3Igor V. Sazanovich,4James T. Pegg,5Qiang Zhu,2Zhongfu Pang,2Rong-Jia Wei,1Mike Towrie,4Kim E. Jelfs,5Marc A. Little,2,*and Andrew I. Cooper2,6,*

In the1H NMR, the disappearance of the aldehyde singlet at 10.4 ppm and theappearance of a singlet at 8.54 ppm indicated the clean formation of 1,w h i c hw a scon?rmed using HR-MS by the peak at m/z= 841.3081 assigned to [3+2] cageproduct. The structure of 1was also con?rmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction(SC-XRD) after growing crystals by slowly diffusing n-pentane into a solution of 1in 1,4-dioxane. Under these conditions, 1crystallizes as an inclusion complex with1,4-dioxane ( 1,2,Figure 2 , where 2= 1,4-dioxane) that has a crystal packingarrangement of 1referred to as 1a0.I n1,2,c a g e 1has a propeller-like shape ( Fig-ure 2 A) and is packed to form a 2-dimensional (2D) lamellar-like structure ( Figure 2 B).
